messageBody:
Quoth Bill de hÓra:
> Steven Taschuk wrote:
> > Quoth Bill de hÓra:
[...]
> >>[...] This seems to introduce cycles in Java packages [...]
> >
> > Is there a problem with having such cycles?
>
> Glad you asked. Normally I'd say yes - you don't want cycles in an
> object graph. In this case I'm not so sure it's a problem, because
> it might just be my own private definition of what clean code looks
> like and Java seems more forgiving than C++ wrt cycles. [...]

I'm sorry, but I didn't follow your explanation -- I'm still
confused about why dependency cycles among objects are a bad
thing. (Perhaps I missed the reason clearly stated in the snipped
text, in which case I hope you will patiently explain it again.)

Here's a silly example of what I think we're talking about, for
concreteness.

// a list
class FooList {
// the nodes which comprise this list
FooNode[] nodes;
// ...
}

// an element of a list
class FooNode {
// the list of which this node is a member
FooList list;
// ...
}

Here, as you see, FooList refers to FooNode and vice versa.

Now, what specifically might I want to do with the code above that
is more difficult because of this circularity? The only thing I
can think of is incremental compilation, which is certainly tricky.

> [...] And I'm
> pretty sure Gamma and Beck and the legion of developers that use and
> extend JUnit know about dependency cycles. [...]

As I'm sure the above makes clear, I don't know much of interest
about them.
